718059f-a.text:
Canal Street, western end, from West to Greenwich Streets, looking across what used to be the little park between the north fork of Canal Street and the south fork (formerly Eoboken Street). This little park is now being cleared off and made into a triangular
safety zone.
August 29, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

718058f-b.text:
Canal Street, south side, east from Greenwich (9th Avae-e "E;" thereon), to Matts (left) Streets, shoving a triangular block bounded bv these thoroughfares. A former 4 storv structure (No. 50O Canal and 477 Greenxich Streets)has been replaced by a gasoline station and opened to viex the side of a frame house No. 475 Greenwich Street. Adjacent to same is a siaular 2 1/2 story frame ouilding ithn brick front, bearing No. 473. Across t'ese buildinas apoears lofts on the aouth side of satts SEreet; the narrowerof which is to be rebuilt and 'ave a modern tra slucent glass front. For an account of same see the Ne v York Times of October 20, 1937, pame 42 L. V;w No. 2 shows details of tbe atructures occupying the riddle of this block front. The narrow 2 story affAir at the left is a rear ertrance to an addition to tbe aforerentioned 1 o 273 Greenwick Street. The ad foirinm oroperty (So's. 496 and 498 Canal Street) is composed of 2 units; ore, two stories in heimyt and thie other, one story. Note the doorwav leading into the hacl vard of the firat 2 1/2 story frame dwelling. In this innstance the photographer is iewing towards Greenwich Street and upon ehich apnear lofts on the vest side of same. View No. 3 is sirular to No. 1. Note at the left the ahaence of tw: d story brick structure and the cas station repplacing same, thereby giving this front an additional vacancv. The 12 story factory at that margin replaced the 3 story pitched roof residences that ap ear to the left in 1c No. 1.
Qctober 25, 1927.
View 2: June 30, 1931
P.L. Snerr  View 3: 1932.
J. Clarence Davis Collection
